# Create two "subplots" and a "figure" using matplotlib
fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(2, 1, figsize=(20, 25))

# Create a bar plot on the "ax1" subplot
temp1.plot.bar(ax=ax1, x=temp1.index, y=temp1.values)
temp2.plot.bar(ax=ax2, x=temp2.index, y=temp2.values)

# Formatting of titles etc. for each subplot
ax1.set(title='Country of Launch', ylabel='frequency', xlabel='Country');
ax2.set(title='Companys Country of Origin', ylabel='frequency', xlabel='Country');

source.00f64a99:
suc_df = df[df['Private or State Run']=='P']

tot = suc_df['Status Mission'].count()
print("Total missions from Private = ", tot)
suc = suc_df[suc_df['Status Mission']=='Success']['Status Mission'].count()
print("Success missions from Private = ", suc)
print("Success rate of Private = ", round(100 * suc/tot,1),'%')
source.6f90cb7e:

print("Success missions from State = ", suc)
print("Success rate of State = ", round(100 * suc/tot,1),'%')

source.7a886ecb:
1 Introduction

The industry of international space exploration has greatly advanced since World War II and the Nuclear Arms Race. Following the Soviet Union’s launch of Sputnik, the space race ensued, with countries developing satellites, rockets, and other technologies to further explore outer space. With this rapid growth of the new Space Industry comes the question of whether the privatization of outer space is fair and equitable for all nations.

Prior to 2004 private space travel was considered as illegal. In 2004 Commercial Space Launch Amendments Act was introduce to ripped away the limitations of space travel and allowed private resources to enter into spcae exploration. With the successful takeoff of the SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket on 30 May 2020, marked a new era in human spaceflight and new era in the privatisation of space.

The dataset for this project was collected from kaggle Privatization of Space. The data I investigate here consists of records of every Space launch from 1957 to the Modern-day.
source.0f515b41: We have two outcomes, one with probability (p) and the other with probability (1-p) of succes, so we know the binomial distribution is the right tool for this analysis.
source.2eeae1c5:
5 Next Steps

Overall this dataset appears to be good quality. The data is mostly categorical. The only variable we dropped was the cost per rocket that has more than 78% missing data. If we can obtaine the cost per rocket launch we can further compare how cost effective the private vs state launches.

source.4d387d77:
By looking at the graph for the number of launches per year, we can see higher number of launches during cold war era. NASA suspend it's shuttle program after 2002 and we can see between 2002-2014 we can see drop of the number of launches.
After 2015 we can see number of launches increases due to the increase launches by private cooperations.
